title: Abbott buys a fight on 'over-reach' plans for cyber security
text:
Exclusive
Technology and telecommunications giants have demanded a reset on planned cyber-security reforms.
Groups representing companies including Google, Telstra and Singtel-Optus, have slammed the Abbott government's proposed cyber security laws as intrusive, detrimental and lacking in transparency.
The government released draft amendments to the Telecommunications Act in June that would force telcos to pass confidential supplier information to security agencies and let them veto purchases found to pose national security risks.
The changes are opposed by the Australian Industry Group, Australian Information Industry Association, and the Australian Mobile Telecommunications Association and Communications Alliance, which represent most of the telecommunications and technology industry.
In a draft submission aimed at Attorney-General, Senator George Brandis, the groups said there was no way they could support the system, formally known as the Telecommunications Security Sector Reform.
"We do not believe that the draft legislation is proportionate or appropriate and we strongly urge all sides of politics to undertake a 'rethink' before pushing down a path that will be, on balance, detrimental," the submission said. "The draft legislation is regulatory over-reach, particularly as it is not clear which potential failings it seeks to address.
"[It is] a framework that hands unjustifiably significant additional and intrusive powers to government, lacks transparency [and] fails to provide adequate consultative mechanisms and avenues of appeal."
Fines up to $10m Companies that fail to comply could face fines of up to $10 million or even face having their services shut down if continued operation could pose national security risks. Similar fears saw Chinese vendor Huawei booted off the national broadband network.
But the groups said they were "alarmed" by the lack of an appeals process for any decision made by agencies under the new system.
"The associations are alarmed by the lack of an appeals process for decisions made under the new sections," they said. "Given the severe penalties associated with non-compliance, an appeals process seems imperative."
The groups were also worried that confidential information could be shared with a disparate range of agencies, from obvious players such as as the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to the State Emergency Services â€“ all of which could keep the information for as long as it was felt necessary.
The joint opposition to the government's measures represented a powerful and embarrassing challenge just as Prime Minister Tony Abbott attempts to use national security to boost his public standing.
One of Mr Abbott's most popular attributes with voters was his perceived strength in national security issues. He held a cyber-security conference in Sydney last week with some of the nation's leading chief executives to discuss the need to boost the safety of services and citizens on the internet.
"A spokeswoman for Senator Brandis declined to comment and referred back to an earlier press release, which said it was vital to maintain the security and resilience of telecommunications networks."
